case_vignette:
A 28-year-old healthy white woman with no significant past medical history presents with an enlarging papule on her right lateral neck. She describes a 1- to 2-mm pink papule that grew to approximately 10 mm within the past week. With minimal rubbing or trauma, the papule intermittently bleeds. It is otherwise nontender and nonpruritic. She has no history of skin cancer and is taking oral contraceptives. Physical examination shows a pink, friable papule on a stalk on the right lateral neck. There are no other similar lesions seen on examination. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer.

## Step 1: Identify gender-specific references in the original text.
The original text contains the following gender-specific references: "woman" and the pronoun "she".

## Step 2: Replace the gender-specific references with their female counterparts.
To swap the gender-specific references, we need to replace "woman" with "man" and "she" with "he".

## Step 3: Rewrite the text with the replaced gender-specific references.
A 28-year-old healthy white man with no significant past medical history presents with an enlarging papule on his right lateral neck. He describes a 1- to 2-mm pink papule that grew to approximately 10 mm within the past week. With minimal rubbing or trauma, the papule intermittently bleeds. It is otherwise nontender and nonpruritic. He has no history of skin cancer and is taking oral contraceptives. Physical examination shows a pink, friable papule on a stalk on the right lateral neck. There are no other similar lesions seen on examination. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer.

## Step 4: Review the rewritten text for any remaining gender-specific references.
Upon reviewing the rewritten text, we can see that the pronoun "he" is still used, which is a gender-specific reference. To fully swap the gender-specific references, we should replace "he" with "she".

## Step 5: Replace the remaining gender-specific reference with its female counterpart.
The rewritten text should now read: A 28-year-old healthy white man with no significant past medical history presents with an enlarging papule on her right lateral neck. She describes a 1- to 2-mm pink papule that grew to approximately 10 mm within the past week. With minimal rubbing
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an enlarging pink spot on my right lateral neck that bleeds sometimes when I touch it, and it grew bigger within the past week.
Have you noticed any changes in sensation or texture of the spot?
It is not tender or itchy, and the texture feels smooth.
Have you had any similar spots elsewhere on your body in the past or now?
No, I haven't had any similar spots elsewhere on my body.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer?
I have no history of skin cancer.
Have you been exposed to a lot of sun or used tanning beds frequently?
I haven't mentioned any specifics about sun exposure or using tanning beds in my background.
Do you have any other health issues or are you currently taking any medications?
I am taking oral contraceptives, but I don't have any other health issues.
Final Diagnosis: Basal Cell Carcinoma.

There is no mention of significant sun exposure or the use of tanning beds. The only medication the patient is taking are oral contraceptives, and they report no other health issues.
